Description: Pottery lamp with banded decoration in black around the rim and sides; wheel-made, open shape, with incurved sides and a flattened rim. A central tube possibly rises level with the rim. Nozzle missing. Black stripes encircle top. Black glaze inside and out. Brown clay, apparently without mica.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Marked in pencil on base "4" = number 4 in list of terracotta lamps in manuscript 'Antiquities from Naukratis (Nebeireh). Inventory of Collection sent to Boston, US', p. 11. Closest parallels for this form are from Athens, though fabric does not look convincing for this origin; another Greek or Cypriot origin is possible (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q38 from Athens). Fabric and decoration resembles that of East Greek Archaic lamps found at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1971,1224.9;GR 1886,0401.1336; Bristol Museum H2768). Parallel from Athens (Howland 1958, Type 12A). Parallels from Sardis (end of the 6th century BC and before a 499 BC destruction layer) and Megara Hyblaea (Bailey 1977, 95). See GR 1888,0601.147 and 1971,1224.9 also from Naukratis. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.06) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4830 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
